s.text: She and her colleagues could trust him to win peace without appeasement.
Annan is a true internationalist: He speaks English, French, and several African languages fluently.

He has spent his life as an "international civil servant," a phrase that conjures an image of someone wasting millions of U.S. dollars pushing paper around the Third World (which is basically what he did).
On paper, Annan isn't a promising candidate to reunite the United States and the United Nations.
He has lived in Geneva, Nairobi, Cairo, Accra, and New York, among other places.

To the rest of the world, U.S. foreign policy is "We're Number One-ism"--an insufferable combination of gloating and bullying.
In the Byzantine, languorous U.N. bureaucracy, Annan earned a reputation as someone who actually Got Things Done.
In the Byzantine, languorous U.N. bureaucracy, Annan earned a reputation as someone who actually Got Things Done.
A U.N. secretary-general is a CEO, someone who needs to be independent enough to take the initiative but tractable enough to heed his board members (that is, the member states).
